Can form large social groups (which contain a larger proportion of young/juveniles in the summer). Can reach local densities of 40-50 ind/km^2 in ecotones (abandoned olive groves which have been partly recolonized, pastures with some scrubs, meadows, and grasslands. Groups of up to tens of individuals. Females and younf individuals cannot rely on large antlers for defence. "In our study area, behavioural interference has been reported between the fallow deer and the roe deer, with the latter being displaced by the former from shared feeding grounds, also through direct aggression, and being less abundant in areas with high densities of fallow deer" "Most likely, wolves detected fallow deer groups in open, lowland grounds, easier than roe deer, which mainly attended concealing habitats". Culled for population control purposes

Gregarious mostly in winter (group size increases with habitat openess, but usually less than 10 individuals) in other seasons generally just solitary individuals or a mother with fawns. "Most likely, wolves detected fallow deer groups in open, lowland grounds, easier than roe deer, which mainly attended concealing habitats".

Terrain here does not allow for escape to higher elevations. In this SA they prefer mosaic of different habitat types . Better adapted (morphologically and behaviourally) to snow than other boreal ungulates as they have large dewclaws, foot loading 2.3 times smaller than moose. wolves usually fall behind when reindeer escape into deep snow, reindeer are faster than wolves on hard surfaes like lake ice (where reindeer comonly use to rest) (see discussion for sources). spatially sedentary during winter with a mean winter home range of 155km^2. Most vulnerable to wolves during autumn rut and early winter.
